description: From Middle English mannish, mannisshe, mannysh, from earlier mennish (“human", also "humanity, mankind”), from Old English mennisċ (“human, natural, humane", also "mankind, human race”), from Proto-West Germanic *mannisk, from Proto-Germanic *manniskaz (“human”), from Proto-Germanic *mann- (“man, human, person”), from Proto-Indo-European *man- (“man”); synchronically analyzable as man +‎ -ish. Doublet of mennish, mensk, mense, and mensch.

adjectives.description: mannish (comparative more mannish, superlative most mannish)

entries.meaning: (of a woman) Resembling or characteristic of a man, masculine. [from 16th c. (from 14th c. in Middle English)]
Resembling or characteristic of a grown man (as opposed to a boy); mature, adult. [from 16th c.]

examples: “They could have saved his life because he was still living, one woman said when she told the police that the boy was alive he said leave him to die, he’s wanted,” Giddings cried, adding that “I know he bad, he mannish, he does misbehave but I never know he was wanted… how can they make the claim without medical assistance.”

entries.meaning: (archaic) Resembling or characteristic of a human being, in form or nature; human. [from 16th c. (from 9th c. in Anglo-Saxon)]
examples: The Westron was a Mannish speech, though enriched and softened under Elvish influence.
